thread.title: China's Stocks Rise to One-Month High Amid Monetary Speculation
thread.title_full: China's Stocks Rise to One-Month High Amid Monetary Speculation - Bloomberg Business

author: Bloomberg.com
title: China's Stocks Rise to One-Month High Amid Monetary Speculation
text:
China’s stocks rose, sending the benchmark index to a one-month high, on speculation the government will take more steps to bolster economic growth.
The Shanghai Composite Index climbed 1.6 percent to 3,236.65 at 10:09 a.m. The gauge has advanced 6.1 percent since financial markets resumed trading on Thursday after a week-long holiday, with turnover picking up. Trading volumes climbed 4.5 percent above the 30-day average for this time of day. Property and material shares jumped after Premier Li Keqiang said the nation will increase fiscal support for shantytown redevelopment.
The People’s Bank of China has cut the amount of cash lenders must set aside as reserves three times this year and reduced interest rates four times since November, as the economy heads for its weakest annual expansion in more than two decades. Policy makers will lower the reserve ratio to 17.5 percent in the fourth quarter from 18 percent now, according to a Bloomberg survey.
“Given the weakness in the economy, the expectations are quite strong about a cut in interest rates and reserve-requirement ratios,” said Zhang Haidong, chief strategist at Jinkuang Investment Management in Shanghai, who’s adding to his holdings. “The market is picking this up and the confidence is back.”
The Shanghai gauge has rebounded 11 percent from the August low as the government targeted support for important industries such as autos and property to bolster growth. Premier Li said the government will also increase tax support for shantytown development, according to a statement on the State Council website on Saturday.
Economic Data This month, China has cut the purchase tax on vehicles with engines 1.6 liters or smaller by half to 5 percent, effective through the end of next year, and announced it had cut the minimum down-payment requirements for first-time homebuyers.
The CSI 300 Index rose 1.7 percent. Hong Kong’s Hang Seng China Enterprises Index advanced 1.8 percent. The Hang Seng Index gained 1.2 percent.
China will release export and consumer-price data on Tuesday and Wednesday, respectively. Overseas shipments probably dropped 6 percent last month from a year earlier, while the inflation rate slowed to 1.8 percent, according to the median estimates of Bloomberg surveys.
During the Oct. 1-7 holiday break, the government released data showing the official purchasing managers’ index advanced to 49.8 in September. While the index showed manufacturing stabilizing, it remains below the 50 level that indicates an expansion.
Rally Fails In August, Thomas Schroeder correctly predicted a rebound in Chinese stocks wouldn’t last. Now, he says, the gauge will plumb new lows as a bear-market rally fails.
The Shanghai Composite will climb 29 percent to 4,100 in the next three months, before slumping as much as 41 percent to 2,400 in early 2016, Schroeder, the Bangkok-based founder and managing director of Chart Partners Group Ltd., said in an interview in Singapore. Schroeder, a former Asian technical analysis chief at UBS Group AG, cited triangle and wedge patterns in making his call.
In a draft rule aimed at strengthening oversight of program trading, the China Securities Regulatory Commission said on Friday traders planning to do algorithmic trading should report and be reviewed before starting. Trading orders shouldn’t originate from offshore systems or domestic systems that are remotely controlled by overseas computers, according to the proposal.
